captions.text:
Fossil records tell us that about 250 million
years ago, there wasn't a tree on Earth designed

to survive in temperatures below freezing.
They were all built for life in the tropics,

where it's always warm, water is always liquid,
and leaves are safe year-round without fear
of frost.

If you took a tropical tree (whether ancient
or modern) and transported it to Siberia or

Patagonia in winter, its water would freeze
into sharp-edged ice crystals, fatally puncturing

the living cells in all of its leaves. The
same thing that happens to lettuce and spinach
when it freezes.

Cold weather also means that water in the
tree's plumbing system freezes, and dangerous

bubbles form in the ice from air that was
previously dissolved in the liquid water.

The ice itself doesn't cause much harm, but
when it thaws, the bubbles remain, which is

a problem because the whole plumbing system
relies on the inter-molecular attraction of

water molecules pulling each other upward
against gravity. Air bubbles break the chain

of molecules, essentially shutting off the
flow of water.

So to survive in cold weather, trees need
to avoid two things: bubbles in their pipes

and direct damage to living cells due to ice
crystals.

They solved the first problem before ever
leaving hot climates, because air bubbles

are also a problem during drought. When plants
work harder to get water from the soil, their

water-conducting pipes can accidentally suck
in tiny pockets of air from the surrounding

tissue. To combat this, trees in the dry tropics
developed skinnier pipes, which, thanks to

the counterintuitive physics of bubbles, develop
fewer bubble blockages than the high-capacity

pipes of their wet-tropical cousins. So the
plumbing of ancestral drought-adapted trees

was accidentally pre-adapted to the cold as
well, well before they began to spread beyond
the tropics.

Upon arriving in cold places, trees then evolved
two techniques they still use to avoid frozen

leaves: one is to fill living leaf cells with
concentrated sugary sap, a biological version

of anti-freeze. Some trees -- mostly evergreen
conifers like pines or spruce -- use solely

this technique and keep their needle-like
leaves unfrozen year-round with a super strong

anti-freeze. But other species, like maples
and birches and larches, combine a less extreme

level of sugar in their leaves with the practice
of going leafless during the winter to avoid
foliar frostbite.

These techniques are uniquely cold-beating
adaptations - well, they were, until descendants

of leaf-dropping trees made it back to the
dry tropics, where their strategy helps them

deal with the extended seasonal droughts that
occur in monsoonal climates.

As far as we know, sugary sap remains the
only adaptation that's only useful in cold

places, which is why you have to come to the
north if you want to tap into the sweet, sweet,

anti-freeze that might just help you survive
the winter - we call it maple syrup.

comments.author: Nels Danielson

comments.text:
You make some nice counter points and while I still see the many flawed 
fundamental presumptions I would like to address by giving my answer for 
each one, I'll just cede the last word to you. Nice to see some people can 
still hash things out like adults. Kudos bro.

God Bless.
comments.author: Nels Danielson

comments.text:
+Nels Danielson "I didn't mean to insinuate that any theory of where the 
universe came from is provable. We can both agree that there is no way to 
know what truly caused the universe to begin, evidence will only get you so 
far, there comes a point where the universe just came to be and nobody can 
say definitively what caused it because the universe only displays a 
timeline from that point on. We're in agreement there."

*No I did not say there is no way to truly know. I said we don't know as 
yet, and we have no evidence which points to a cause. That is a presumption 
based on your preconceived beliefs. Where is your evidence of a cause?*

"In terms of "more possibilities" enlighten me! If you have another theory 
as to how the universe fundamentally began SHARE. That's how people learn 
from each other. Obviously I know there are other possibilities out there, 
I was just stating two of the most prevalent."

*I don't have any theories. But creationism is not a theory. It is a 
hypothesis at best and is contradicted by the evidence. Find me a fossil 
rabbit, human, dog, cat, elephant etc in the Precambrian rock strata or 
Jurassic rock strata or in any other rock strata in which evolution 
predicts it shouldn't be found. Or explain to me in creationist terms why 
we only find these fossils in the rock strata which is predicted by 
evolutionary theory.*
*Why is there no human fossil in the same rock strata as Australopithecus 
for example.* 

"While you might call "Creationism" a "fairy-tale" it does a much better 
job of explaining the origin of everything than any atheist theory I've 
heard."

*Atheism is not a theory and contains no theories. It is the rejection of 
theism and theistic based theories.*

"Creationism is one answer. We can keep searching all we want but until we 
find definitive proof that any one theory is true, your answer is as good 
as mine." 

*Creationism contradicts the evidence. That is never good.*

"But please enlighten me as to how you can get something from nothing?"

*I did NOT claim you can get something from nothing. I don't even know what 
nothing is? Please provide evidence of nothing.*

"If you do then it never was nothing to begin with because it spawned 
something. Everything had to have come from some intrinsic source."

*Firstly we don't have "nothing" to examine to test if something can come 
from it.*
*Secondly I have never seen something come from something. We have seen 
things rearranged to form something else. Eg. wood glue and nails used to 
make a table. The table did not come from the wood glue and nails. Wood, 
glue and nails were simply rearranged into what we label a "table".*

*So PLEASE provide clarity on what you mean when you say "everything had to 
have come from an intrinsic source" and give me examples because I have no 
idea what you mean.*

"In terms of the "1000's of peer reviewed scientific journals", have you 
ever considered the fact that the earth was created as if it had existed 
for eons. Maybe God just made the earth in a state that was set up and 
ready with processes underway that LOOK like they have been going on for 
billions of years but never actually happened. If God were to make a good 
bottle of wine he wouldn't just make a fresh un-aged bottle, he would make 
it pre-aged."

*No. I have not considered that story nor have I considered the one where 
spiritual owls farted the universe into existence 14 billion years ago and 
died in the process, because the evidence has not lead to that conclusion.*

"He could have done the same with the earth. Old-Earth supporters like to 
point out how we can see light from stars much further than 7,000 
light-years away. But if God created the universe 7,000 years ago he 
wouldn't have made stars and then been like "Oh darn now we have to wait 
for the light to reach the earth..." he would have just created the light 
already having been radiating outwards.

*Please provide me with evidence in support of this claim.*

"So you may subscribe to the philosophy of "following the evidence", but 
that evidence could be from a cycle or event that never actually occurred, 
but just looks that way because it was created to look that way. If I were 
God I would have created the earth pre-aged as well. This time in the 
planetary calendar is quite optimal for life and humans in particular. "

*It could be, but you have still not provide any rational reason to believe 
it is. Following the evidence is the only method which has continually 
worked in scientific discovery. If you have a better method than following 
the evidence, please share.*

"So again there is no way to prove any theory definitively true. But you 
can still look at likelihood, and you tell me which is more likely: All of 
these beautiful, systematic, intricate, perfectly functioning systems of 
life and matter simply coming into existence and working perfectly by sheer 
chance, or having been planned and created by a master designer."

*It's not about which I think is more likely. It is about the evidence. 
Fossil records show life evolve from single cellular life forms and adapted 
to operate successfully in the environments in which it found itself in.*
*The life forms which could not adapt died off.*
*99.99% of all species are now extinct. Your designer must be awfully bad 
at his job.*
comments.author: TheDash

comments.text:
+35dasher I didn't mean to insinuate that any theory of where the universe 
came from is provable. We can both agree that there is no way to know what 
truly caused the universe to begin, evidence will only get you so far, 
there comes a point where the universe just came to be and nobody can say 
definitively what caused it because the universe only displays a timeline 
from that point on. We're in agreement there.

In terms of "more possibilities" enlighten me! If you have another theory 
as to how the universe fundamentally began SHARE. That's how people learn 
from each other. Obviously I know there are other possibilities out there, 
I was just stating two of the most prevalent.

While you might call "Creationism" a "fairy-tale" it does a much better job 
of explaining the origin of everything than any atheist theory I've heard. 
Creationism is one answer. We can keep searching all we want but until we 
find definitive proof that any one theory is true, your answer is as good 
as mine. But please enlighten me as to how you can get something from 
nothing? If you do then it never was nothing to begin with because it 
spawned something. Everything had to have come from some intrinsic source.

In terms of the "1000's of peer reviewed scientific journals", have you 
ever considered the fact that the earth was created as if it had existed 
for eons. Maybe God just made the earth in a state that was set up and 
ready with processes underway that LOOK like they have been going on for 
billions of years but never actually happened. If God were to make a good 
bottle of wine he wouldn't just make a fresh un-aged bottle, he would make 
it pre-aged. He could have done the same with the earth. Old-Earth 
supporters like to point out how we can see light from stars much further 
than 7,000 light-years away. But if God created the universe 7,000 years 
ago he wouldn't have made stars and then been like "Oh darn now we have to 
wait for the light to reach the earth..." he would have just created the 
light already having been radiating outwards.

So you may subscribe to the philosophy of "following the evidence", but 
that evidence could be from a cycle or event that never actually occurred, 
but just looks that way because it was created to look that way. If I were 
God I would have created the earth pre-aged as well. This time in the 
planetary calendar is quite optimal for life and humans in particular. 

So again there is no way to prove any theory definitively true. But you can 
still look at likelihood, and you tell me which is more likely: All of 
these beautiful, systematic, intricate, perfectly functioning systems of 
life and matter simply coming into existence and working perfectly by sheer 
chance, or having been planned and created by a master designer.

God Bless.
comments.author: Nels Danielson

comments.text:
+Nels Danielson
"Well I'll prove mine when you prove yours haha. their is absolutely no way 
for either of us to prove the other wrong." 

*No. I could link you to 1000's of peer reviewed scientific journals which 
all come to the same conclusions on the diversity of life.* *Life evolved. 
That's not a belief. That is where the evidence leads and is the theory 
which best explains the fossil record and diversity of life. It is also 
proven further by our study of genetics.*

"Either the universe was created by another true reality (Intelligent 
Designer) or it came to be from no reality (Something from Nothing?) but i 
digress."

*Is your brain that limited that it can only come up with those two 
possibilities? And why did the topic switch from biology to cosmology 
somehow.*

"Neither of us were their when the universe began so we can't determine 
whose right."

*I care about where the evidence leads. We did not need to be there to 
examine the evidence.*

"However I have a very particular reason for believing what I do. Any 
theory that rejects the idea of intelligent designer cannot explain how the 
universe came to be other than saying "It has always existed".

*No, there are many scientific theories on the matter that propose that the 
universe had a beginning and many which do not, and non of them need an 
"intelligent designer" to explain it.*
*The simple fact is that we do not yet know for certain. And until such 
time as someone can successfully prove their theory, we cannot know. In the 
mean time we don't make up fairy-tale stories. We keep searching to find 
the answers.*
 
"Now this notion does seem maybe possible somehow but I find the idea that 
there was some reality outside this universe and outside time itself to be 
much much more logical."

*I don't care what you find logical. Or what others might feel is logical. 
I care about where the evidence leads.*

"You can think what you want but don't tell me you can prove it any more 
than I can prove my belief,"

*I don't have any beliefs regarding the beginning of the universe. I simply 
do not know.*

" and don't tell me I am wrong for believing what I do because it's just as 
plausible as your theory, and seems more logical to me be it not that way 
for you. "

*I don't have any theory. I simply do not know. Its not about what you 
believe or what I believe. It's about where the evidence leads. I will 
follow the evidence when it presents itself.*
comments.author: TheDash

comments.text: +35dasher Lol just saw your profile pic. Practice what you preach bro.
comments.author: Nels Danielson

comments.text:
+35dasher Well I'll prove mine when you prove yours haha. their is 
absolutely no way for either of us to prove the other wrong. Either the 
universe was created by another true reality (Intelligent Designer) or it 
came to be from no reality (Something from Nothing?) but i digress. Neither 
of us were their when the universe began so we can't determine whose right.

However I have a very particular reason for believing what I do. Any theory 
that rejects the idea of intelligent designer cannot explain how the 
universe came to be other than saying "It has always existed". Now this 
notion does seem maybe possible somehow but I find the idea that there was 
some reality outside this universe and outside time itself to be much much 
more logical.

You can think what you want but don't tell me you can prove it any more 
than I can prove my belief, and don't tell me I am wrong for believing what 
I do because it's just as plausible as your theory, and seems more logical 
to me be it not that way for you. 

God Bless.
comments.author: Nels Danielson

comments.text:
+Nels Danielson Evidently it happens on its own through a process called 
evolution through natural selection. Life which is not suited to the 
environment either adapt or die off.

Unless you can prove that the orange flamingo named Yahweh hiding under the 
surface of Pluto just popped them into existence like all creationist 
claim, we have no reason to take that claim seriously.

If you claim that the orange flamingo just guides the process but cannot 
provide evidence of it ever existing never mind guiding the process, than 
you've just made an assertion which we can ignore with Occums razor.

Prove your position or move on!

comments.author: Biscuit Ninja

comments.text:
+Link Hyrule An overdose refers to when you have taken enough to cause harm 
right there and then. Meth won't usually kill you in one dose unless you 
have taken a lot of Meth.
comments.author: restlesswikiinfo

comments.text:
+restlesswikiinfo All drugs are dangerous in overdoses, no matter the kind. 
It just so happens some, like Meth, require much less to overdose. But 
regardless, the right amount of Morphine will kill you just as quickly as 
the right amount of Meth or Cocaine or any other drug.
comments.author: Link Hyrule

comments.text:
They don't wear lab coats unless people jut them on trees, mainly because a 
lab coat is only useful if there is something to avoid. Like dangerous 
chemicals. Also, stop associating chemical with danger. Literally 
everything physical you can hold is a chemical, oxygen, carbon dioxide, 
uranium, wood, (the things from trees not drugs although drugs are 
chemicals too). Also don't associate drug with danger too, classify them 
into over the counter drugs, most drugs in a pharmacy, the kind you don't 
need a prescription for, prescription drugs, the ones your pharmacist or 
doctor fills out a form for after analyzing your condition, and illegal 
drugs, Cocaine, Meth, in some places Hash and Marijuana. Drugs in common 
terminology refers to the latter in most cases, but the former two are very 
useful in some cases, would you like to feel pain during a surgery?
comments.author: restlesswikiinfo
